Don't fall for the narrative and spin that manufacturers push to get more money.

Because the price point I have always bought gpus at, has basically become the 50 series now. And thats just the price point.

Inflation up 34% since 2014. Gpu's up like 67%. Price only, not to mention the die size we get shrinking. Im pretty done with it.

comments.text:
The more I look at the gpu market decline since the 1000 series. The more mad I get. I have bought one gpu since the gtx 900 series. And well...i see no reason still to buy a new one. Even tho mine is 5 years old 5700xt. The offerings for the price points. Are just not urging to do anything but keep playing old games and ignoring the offerings by both companies. If pre 2020 you could build a PC that beats console for the same price. But post 2020 you cant even come close to it, then something has to change.

No, buying used parts and jank stuff off ali baba and ebay is not a legitimate solution. You used to be able to do it with new parts. Now, you can BARELY even do that with used and janky stuff. The gpu market, is awful. And they gotta bring back some value.

Looking forward to the 8gb not enough miss information video coming soon where you force settings that would get you sub 30 fps in game and say see guys not enough vram. Also nice argument against steam hardware survey proving you wrong. "well people don't have a choice at that price range so of course everyone has a 4060" Two things with that. 1. what about all the 12/16gb amd cards near that price range? You say it's all about vram but people still avoid the higher vram amd cards in that price range why? 2. Are you going to tell those hundreds of thousands of people the 4060s that they can't play games because they only have 8gb vram. They used the card happily for years so they would be very confused when mr hobo man comes and tries to tell them "no you can't play games it's not enough stop it!!!!" 

I just don't get where in your ego you think your 4k ultra setting cherry picked examples of running out of vram for a 1080p gpu has more value or logic than a company that will spend millions on data collection every year to understand what is enough. They know full well the vast majority of people buying budget 60 class gpus are playing at 1080p and they also know full well playing at 1080p 8gb is more than enough. Why is it enough? Because games are created by console specs. There has not been an increase in vram in consoles in the past 5 years and their wont be till the next gen xbox and playstation. Every single time you have tried to argue 8gb not enough you are sitting there playing 1440p ultra ray tracing or 4k ultra settings like nooo way running out of vram guys oh noes, completely ignorant to the unrealistic settings for that class of gpu that no one would ever use because it doesn't have the performance to play those settings anyway. All these people are playing 1080p max settings or 1440p with dlss and have enough vram they aren't making cards that can't play games what kind of a brainless take are you giving? This card like really only targets the old radeon GPUs it looks like, considering it can match a 7700xt and sometimes it even went higher then the 7800xt, the power draw at sub 200 watts is also sort of nice, but it definitely also seems like a not good card. Considering the rx 9070 is supposed to only be around 100 more (which it unfortunately is not right now) it is definitely a bad buy, perhaps good for like 300 - 350 but no more. Getting something good for little money right now really is not possible it seems like, be it the used or new market you can't exactly get something good for a good price (and that is not even accounting the power draw something like a 3080 has, that may be a really good used buy as I saw them at a 400 mark but they chug power). And it doesn't help that games become more demanding as well, so anything cheap right now may not last as long as previously.

Gonna have to wait and see how disappointing the rx 9060 xt and non-xt launch will be, I see no reason for hope considering the rx x600 cards from the last generations were only good for 1080p and that that range even from AMD has pretty much been a 1080p only tier from what it seems like, granted they are cheap cards so at least sort of cost effective, but if AMD manages to pull off like a 7700xt/rtx4070 with their rx 9060 (12gb would also probably be fine for such a tiered card, maybe even 10 gb and hopefully using an entire x16 PCIe so people with gen 3 can use it properly) that would be amazing and I'd guess really the only hope one could have for a good card that doesn't cost half your PC suddenly.

comments.text:
Nvidia next time gpu vram every series

Nice! Lets define the RTX 6000 series starting from RTX 6060 upwards, assuming NVIDIA might follow a new naming convention like they did with the 4000/5000 shift. Here's a realistic and future-proof VRAM suggestion roadmap from RTX 6060 to 6090 Ti:


---

RTX 6060

VRAM: 12GB GDDR7

Target Use: 1080p high settings, entry-level gaming

Why: 8GB is dead for modern AAA games. 12GB is the new minimum even at entry level.



---

RTX 6060 Ti

VRAM: 16GB GDDR7

Target Use: 1080p ultra / 1440p medium-high

Why: Ti should give enough headroom for more demanding titles and longer relevance.



---

RTX 6070

VRAM: 16GB GDDR7

Target Use: 1440p high / 4K low-medium

Why: Mainstream sweet spot. 4070 with 12GB fell short in many new games.



---

RTX 6070 Ti

VRAM: 20GB GDDR7

Target Use: 1440p ultra / 4K high

Why: For users who want RT and textures on high without worrying about VRAM limits.



---

RTX 6080

VRAM: 20GB GDDR7

Target Use: 4K high / RT medium

Why: High-performance card needs room for 4K textures + DLSS/RT overhead.



---

RTX 6080 Ti

VRAM: 24GB GDDR7X

Target Use: 4K ultra / 1440p with max RT

Why: Serious gamers or prosumers, ideal for long-term performance.



---

RTX 6090

VRAM: 2432GB GDDR7X

Target Use: 4K ultra + full RT / AI workloads / creator tasks

Why: Top-tier GPU demands top-tier memory.



---

RTX 6090 Ti / Titan Ada Next

VRAM: 48GB GDDR7X

Target Use: AI/ML, extreme 4K/8K gaming, game devs, creators

Why: Flagship class. Meant for people who dont compromise.



---

Let me know if you want a price target suggestion, or a matching AMD/Radeon RX 9000+ VRAM roadmap too.

comments.text:
ASUS TUF Gaming GeForce RTX 5060 Ti 16GB GDDR7 OC Edition (TUF-RTX5060TI-O16G-GAMING) vs. EVGA RTX 2060 Super SC Ultra Black Gaming (08G-P4-3065-KR) from TechPowerUp:

* Release Date: 2025/04/16 vs. 2019/07/09 (~6 year delta)
* Process: 5nm vs. 12nm
* Interface: PCIe 5.0 x8 vs. PCIe 3.0 x16
* RAM: 16GB vs. 8GB
* CUDA Cores: 4608 vs. 2176
* TMUs: 144 vs. 136
* ROPs: 48 vs. 64
* GPU Clock: 2407/2662 MHz vs. 1470/1650 MHz (base/boost)
* Memory Size: 16GB vs. 8GB
* Memory Clock: 1750 MHz (identical)
* Memory Bus: 128-bit vs. 256-bit
* Memory type: GDDR7 vs. GDDR6
* TDP: 180W vs. 175W
* GPU thermals: 34/60C vs. 49/69C (idle/load)
* Noise: 0-24/29 dBA vs. 0-30/35 dBA (idle/load) (note: 0-X means fan idle to lowest RPM, based on temperature)
* Power Draw: 9/164-209W vs. 8/188W (idle/load)
* MSRP (USD): $429 vs. $399 ($497 in today's market, re: inflation)
* Market Price (USD): $430 (est.) vs. $389 ($484 in today's market, re: inflation)

My own conclusion, based solely on these metrics: the 5060 Ti is the present-day replacement for the going-on-6-years-old 2060 SUPER.  You're getting a better bang for your buck now than you were 6 years ago (when taking inflation into account), aside from the memory bus going from 256-bit to 128-bit.  Lower cost, lower power draw, quieter, cooler, faster clocks, and more RAM.  I'm excluding the ROP variance since I believe the decrease (on the 5060 Ti) is a side effect of the overall GPU architecture changing substantially compared to older Turing.

Do I think it's a great deal?  No (i.e. I agree with Steve/HU).  But when comparing to hardware from 6 years ago, you are getting more for less.  It doesn't make it a great mid-range-priced gaming card, but if you care about the stuff I do (thermals, noise, and power draw), it's an acceptable upgrade.  Would I buy one as an upgrade from a 4060 or 3060?  Probably not, unless there was some particular game I loved that performed substantially better on Blackwell architecture vs. Lovelace or Ampere.

Edge case: the PCIe x8 lanes is a deal-breaker if you plan on buying this card and using it on an older motherboard (such as mine which is PCIe 3.0); it means you're end up with PCIe 3.0 x8 which is half the bandwidth as PCIe 3.0 x16.  Just something to be aware of.  You definitely want a PCIe 5.0 mainboard for this card.

comments.text: Honestly, the 5060Ti is not a bad value (at MSRP). In my country, I can get the ZOTAC 5060Ti 16GB model for $739SGD, which is $563USD, which is as expected in my country where PC parts and tech is generally higher than US MSRP. However, every other model is over $800SGD, some close to and some exceeding $900SGD, which is a total scam as the ZOTAC 5070 is just a bit more expensive than those models with clearly more performance (but less VRAM). Comparing Nvidia cards alone, this makes the 5060Ti ZOTAC model not a terrible value, but I just bought an RX7800XT for $678SGD (on discount) new, which is 1.5 year old GPU that still beats the 5060Ti with the same amount of VRAM but losing in ray tracing. I could've even gone with a second hand RX 6900XT for even cheaper, which would perform even better in rastorised performance. So, unless you're playing a lot of RT games at like 1080p (which if you are, WTF are you doing?), then go for 5060Ti, but if you play at any higher res with RT, get a higher end Nvidia GPU from 4000 series, or go with last gen AMD for pure rastorised gaming performance

comments.text: When averaging performance over N games, it's more meaningful to use a geometric mean than an (arithmetic) mean/average as that preserves the % better/% worse relationships. It also means that you get the same results whether comparing fps or ms/frame. This is calculated by multiplying the 16 values and taking the 16th root (or square root 4 times). How were these 16 game averages calculated?

comments.text:
I've checked 3 of the biggest online retailers here in Germany and you can easily find multiple models of the 5060 Ti 16GB basically for adjusted MSRP (MSRP converted to Euros +19% VAT) IN STOCK.

The cheapest 9070 in stock is 106 over adjusted MSRP.
The cheapest 9070 XT in stock is 134 over adjusted MSRP.
The cheapest 5070 in stock is 36 over adjusted MSRP.

I have 3 possible explanations for this:
1. Either Europe suddenly got red pilled and has higher demand for AMD GPUs (which I highly doubt because most buyers are casuals who only trust NVIDIA)
2. AMD's supply to Europe was and is still horrible..
3. Or maybe it's the rebate system HWU spoke about which makes AMD's MSRP intentionally fake while NVIDIA's fake MSRP could be unintended only happening due to low supply early on that apparently caught up.

I believe this problem is causing AMD to lose sales until they supply or offer the rebates / price cuts to said retailers 6 months later like every generation.. (I know this is focused on Europe and doesn't apply to every other market)

comments.text:
Yeah but 8gb was OTT then, especially running games at 1080p and it wasn't a big deal until relatively recently. All of these reviewers miss the fact that the 4060ti never had to compete with 3060ti. Because the 3060ti doesn't exist as soon as the 4060ti is released. The only thing that matters is the relative difference in performance between each of the cards in a series and how much they cost. When people build a new PC they are very rarely, if ever, going to go only 1 series up. So they'll spec parts and decide whether they're getting a 60, 70, 80 or 90, perhaps with the ti or super variant - and pick their price point. Of course there has to be some bump in performance, or new features at each series, but it doesn't need to be big leap from generation to generation because only a small niche of people upgrade every generation and those people are largely the kind who just buy whatever is new without any regard to price or anything else.

 e.g I went from 1070 to 3060ti - and although the vram didn't change the performance is several fold improvement - as well as adding dlss etc. Chances are high I won't upgrade until 6 series or 7 series - unless a game comes along where I think I really need more vram - closest to that for me is assetto corsa EVO but it runs ok and the devs may well optimise further - it is stretching vram but it's the only game I play regularly that does.

The reason these reviewers who pout and trying to say nvidia sucks whilst nvidia sales and share price rockets is because they are fundamentally clueless about who is buying graphics cards and when and why - and then reach false conclusions. These hardware channels are out of touch - even the resolution they do benchmarks at the steam hardware survey shows you that people aren't using them - and if they think vram usage is a thing why do they only benchmark fps? 56% of steam users use 1080p, 35% have 8gb cards - under 5% at 16gb. Most have 16gb ram. So anyone benchmarking a 16gb card at 4k on a system with 32gb ram and waffling about his opinions? It's just divorced from reality from what the people who end up buying a 5060ti card will do and these won't be 4060ti owners. It's laughable they all said 4060ti was bad, sales were high and now they have a pouty face saying why that doesn't mean they were wrong. It means exactly that and it's nothing to do with AMD.

comments.text:
Graphs are wrong. Different GPUs scale differently between resolutions and they are meant for different monitors. RTX 5060 Ti is 1080p card. So. why no benchmarks on its intended resolution? It can stretch to 1440p, but that is it. It is not intended to be used at 4k. 

I respect thoroughness of this channel, but it does have some issues with its methodology. Another is that in its non-extended benchmarks, it has too many esports games which can wildly twist real performance of GPUs. We saw that with HU RTX 4060 vs RX 7600 reviews where it had failed to properly capture superiority of RTX 4060. Though, it still was a single number difference, but it was double. So, their benchmarks don't really match that well with other reviewers findings. However, their extended benchmarking video properly had shown what difference was supposed to be.

comments.text:
Looking at these results and comparing the "rumored" specs of the RX 9060 XT, my speculation places the RX 9060 XT 16GB version to be a direct equivalent to the RTX 5060 Ti 16GB, and the 8GB will be a direct equivalent to the 8GB.  There are circumstances.  With the rumored specs comparison, areas where the RTX 5060 Ti 16GB meet or barely beat the RTX 4060 Ti 16GB, the RX 9060 XT should provide a stronger result.  Meanwhile for areas where the RTX 5060 Ti 16GB got a much bigger boost, the RX 9060 XT 16GB could be weaker, as these stronger boosts are a result of having sufficient VRAM bandwidth.

Basically saying, gamers need to wait for what AMD delivers with the RX 9060 XT series before considering the RTX 5060 Ti or RTX 5060 models.  I have heard some bad elements, like rumored missing decoders for the RX 9060 XT, which really begs the question why the lower end is so expensive that we have to cut down to only 8 PCIe lane controllers and 4 GDDR memory controllers.  As much as the 8x PCIe lane size is one element, why can't the xx60 series progress up to 6 GDDR memory controllers (192-bit bus)?  If VRAM price was a concern for the RTX 5060 series, GDDR6 and GDDR6X are cheaper than GDDR7.  Taking the RX 7600 XT's VRAM spec as an example, upgrading to a 192-bit bus would provide 432GB/s bandwidth, just 16GB/s less than 128-bit GDDR7 that the RTX 5060 Ti is using, and that is just GDDR6.  I am certain everyone would be happy to see the "6" category to have 12GB of VRAM.  This also points to how GDDR7 isn't giving that big of a performance boost for the rest of the RTX 50 series.  The games are not configured to use it.

This is probably good questions that our tech news channels can reach out to AMD and Nvidia onto "Why are the '6' category video cards stuck with these specs?".  The '6' category for Nvidia has 36 SMs vs AMD's 32 CUs (both having equivalent execution cores configurations), 128-bit bus (4 GDDR memory controllers), and 8x PCIe lanes (8 PCIe controllers).  They are very similar, and they line up with the previous generation's RTX 4060 Ti configuration and RX 7600 XT configuration.  The only performance gain we can have is if clock rates get a magical boost, like the rumors for the RX 9060 XT.

The last statement I have to say, how to rate the RTX 5060 Ti 8GB without review.  Look at the average improvement between the RTX 5060 Ti 16GB and RTX 4060 16GB and add that average to the RTX 4060 Ti 8GB reviews.  Given the 8GB VRAM, whatever pitfalls the RTX 4060 TI 8GB had, the RTX 5060 Ti 8GB will also have the same pitfalls.  Beyond those pitfalls, the RTX 4060 Ti 16GB and 8GB were a match.  It is safe to say that where the 1440p average for raster says the 5060 ti 16GB was 15% faster than the 4060 ti 16GB, the 8GB variant should be a similar 15%.  Where this number will drop is 2025 benchmark selection of games versus the 2023 reviews.

Also according to rumors, there is no RX 9060, just the RX 9060 XT 16GB and 8GB, where the RX 9060 XT 8GB is rumored to price compete against the RTX 5060.  Again, the difference between the 16GB and 8GB "should" be VRAM capacity, meaning the 8GB should be similar in performance to the 16GB except in games where the RTX 4060 Ti 8GB had pitfalls.

Do you guys have a video showing how much VRAM games use / need at various resolutions?

I only ask because the 5060ti or even the 4060 to me are solid 1080p / maybe 1440p cards, I'd love to know if there are any games that using the higher texture settings in games at 1080p / 1440p go over the 8gb to know if its worth it or not!

This is probably pretty tricky to check, as I think alot of games will just allocate the whole vram amount if its available, but would love to see at what thresholds things start becoming a problem. I know some people say "but 4k!" but these are not really usable cards at 4k, so the question really is "do you need more than 8gb for 1440p / 1080p?" obviously more is always better, but since we in theory have the option for the 8gb variant, I'd love to know if that extra $50 would be better off going to a slightly better cpu / bigger ssd etc etc.

Hey steve, will you be able to investigate if there is some form of CPU overhead with the 9070xt?

I have seen quite a few benchmarks in regards to the 9070xt, and it seems that it gets beaten by the 7900xt quite a few times in 1440p but somehow wins 7900xtx at 4k in the same game. It could totally be the inverse too and that the 7000 series having bottleneck at higher res.

However the fact that your CS2(CPU intensive) testing showed the huge discrepancy in FPS between the 7900 series and the 9070 series at 1440p makes me feel that the difference might be even bigger the lower the resolution is.

Will you also be able to investigate other eSport titles too like R6, Rocket league and Valorant too preferably at 1080p or 720p low and see if it is a CS2 only issue, many people play at extremely low resolutions like 1280x960 in the FPS titles and its actual relevant testing.

comments.text:
@RadarLeon I think the RX-9070 is the successor to the RX-7800XT, and the RX-9070XT is the successor to the RX-7900GRE.

The high-end had the RX-7900xt and RX-7900XTX last generation, but there is no high-end AMD cards this generation. I don't think it made much sense anyways, in terms of Scaling Up the RDNA-4, Supply Constraints, Pricing, and the Performance Competition from Nvidia.

I don't think AMD had any decent answer for the plausible RTX-5090Ti, RTX-5090, RTX-5080Ti Super, RTX-5080Ti, and RTX-5080 Super. Even the RTX-5080 (which is a re-badged xx70 card) is questionable.

So think of the RDNA-4, as less like the Polaris Generation (RX-470/480) and more like the Navi Generation (RX-5700 / RX-5700XT). Remember jebaited? Those Navi cards were "midrange" (vs RTX 2060 / RTX 2070) but effectively succeeded the early Vega (V56/V64) cards. With later Navi releases of the low-end RX-5600XT to the RX-5500 entry level cards. Which by the way, the RX-5700 later improved to RTX-2070 level with drivers, and the RX-5700XT to around RTX-2080 level.... as long as you don't rely on Upscaling or Path Tracing. Which is becoming more common, so it is a mixed bag, since the RTX-20 Series really didn't age well.

comments.text:
This happens in a lot of consumer electronics markets these days. Most competitors in a small competitive space don't want to compete on price. If a major player raises prices, they'd rather find out how they can do the same. If there are no competitors, they'd rather find some excuse to raise their prices.

It's as if to them, customers being happy with the price is a sign that they're a bad business by not maximizing their profits. And it sucks that people defend this as some kind of, "well, that's just how you play the game", rather than an attitude problem.
These businesses can't even be honest about how they price their products anymore.

Really looking forward to those GN interviews with companies given the tariff situation.

comments.author: @MemeHook1

comments.text:
When they cut down the Bus Width to 128 they have to choose particular vram configurations that suits the Bus Width.
In the case of 128bit, we're able to put 4 modules or 8 modules (in a kinda dual rank configuration).
This means that using 2GB modules we end up with 8GB and 16GB.

Another example is the 3060 12GB, it had 192 bit bus which means 6x32bit modules of 2GB, ending up at 12GB.
The 8GB version had a cut down bus width to 128bit
